key_insight: AdaTooler-V learns when to call vision tools (for images and videos) instead of invoking them blindly, cutting unnecessary tool use while preserving or improving reasoning performance.
problem_solved: Open-source multimodal LLMs overuse vision tools — invoking expensive vision modules even when not needed — causing higher latency, compute waste, and degraded overall performance.
method: Adaptive tool-use controller that predicts, per query (and per video frame when applicable), whether a vision tool is necessary before invoking it.
Integrates selective tool invocation into multimodal interleaved chain-of-thought reasoning so the model still uses tools when they provide real benefit.
Training with a cost-aware objective (trade-off between accuracy and invocation overhead) and temporal-aware selection for videos to limit frame-level tool calls.
impact: Reduces inference latency and compute cost while maintaining or improving reasoning accuracy for image and video tasks, making multimodal LLM deployments more efficient and scalable.
visual_elements: Flowchart: query → adaptive controller (yes/no) → (if yes) vision tool → reasoning, illustrating decision vs blind invocation.
Bar chart: comparison of tool invocations, latency, and accuracy between blind-tool baseline and AdaTooler-V.
Timeline/strip of video frames showing selective frame-level tool calls vs full-frame processing.
Icon set: magnifying glass (tool), crossed tool (no call), clock (latency), lightning bolt (efficiency)
paper_title: AdaTooler-V: Adaptive Tool-Use for Images and Videos
paper_authors: Chaoyang Wang, Kaituo Feng, Dongyang Chen, Zhongyu Wang, Zhixun Li
